name: Blóðughadda
description:
Blóðughadda
Nine Daughters of Ægir and Rán

Norse Mythology[]
Blóðughadda meaning "Bloody-hair." According to scholar John Lindow this name "refers to reddish foam atop a wave". Scholar Rudolf Simek says that "the name does not appear to be too appropriate for a wave, but perhaps it was supposed to convey the wispy, thread-like appearance of the water streaming from the crest of the wave."
In Norse mythology, the goddess Rán and the Jötunn Ægir both personify the sea, and together they have nine daughters who personify waves. Each daughter's name reflects poetic terms for waves. The sisters are attested in the Poetic Edda, compiled in the 13th century from earlier traditional sources; the Prose Edda, composed in the 13th century; and in the poetry of skalds. Scholars have theorized that these daughters may be the same figures as the nine mothers of the god Heimdallr. In Norse Mythology Heimdall is the child of the Nine Daughters of Ægir and Rán and the God Odin.
In the God of War Series[]
Blóðughadda is one of the daughters of Ægir and Rán. Blóðughadda has eight known sisters, Bylgja, Drǫfn, Dúfa, Hefring, Himinglæva, Hrǫnn, Kólga and Unnr. The daughters were referenced in the Lake of Nine. It is also currently unconfirmed if Heimdall's father is Odin like he is in Norse Mythology.
Trivia[]
In mythology, Blóðughadda, along with all their sisters gave birth to Heimdall at once.
